fields:
Organisations
What are these organisations called and responsible for?
UNHCR – {{c1::Protection, Public Health (co-ordination) UN High Commissioner for Refugees}} 
UNICEF – {{c1::Children’s health and protection, WASH, United Nations Children’s Fund }}
WFP – World Food Programme 
IOM – International Organisation of Migration 
WHO – Health policy, disease surveillance (polio)

Statisics of displaced people - 2019
26M refugees
{{c1::79.5}}M forcibly displaced people
{{c1::45.7}}M Internally displaced persons 
4.2M Asylum seekers
{{c1::1}}% of world's population is displaced

Which UN agency provides care for Palestinian refugees?
{{c1::United Nations Relief Works Agency}}

Which UN agency provides care for all other refugees?
{{c1::UNHCR}}

{{c1::Primary health care co-ordination}} is the principal function of UNHCR Public Health personnel

Which article ensures refugees have access to public health services equivalent to that of the host population? {{c1::Article 23, Refugee Convention of 1951}}

What is the WHO essential drugs reference? {{c1::a list a WHO agreed list of essential drugs for populations in emergencies}}

Name the camp in Kenya which has three generations of refugees. {{c1::Dadaab Camp}}

What is Travel Medicine? 
“Travel medicine is a specialism that deals with the health of {{c1::travellers who visit foreign countries}}. It crosses disciplines and is concerned not only with prevention of infectious diseases during travel but also with personal safety and reduction of environmental risk. Travel medicine specialists should be able to recognise and either treat or refer common tropical infectious diseases in returned travellers.”  (I think he wrote this so prob a question)

What is GeoSentinel Global Surveillance Network? 
Partnership with International Society of Travel Medicine and CDC in Atlanta, Georgia, looks at diseases in travellers

Match these
• Person-to-person contact 
• Bites and stings
• Vector-borne
• Environmental contact 
• Food and water ingestion 

1. Dengue, Malaria, Yellow fever, Zika 
2. Hepatitis B, Influenza, Meningococcal
3. Cholera, Hepatitis A, Typhoid 
4. Jelly fish, Scorpion, Rabies
5. Cutaneous larva migrans, Leptospirosis, Schistosomiasis (he loves this), Tetanus

{{c1::
• Vector-borne – eg, Dengue, Malaria, Yellow fever, Zika 
• Person-to-person contact – eg, Hepatitis B, Influenza, Meningococcal 
• Food and water ingestion – eg, Cholera, Hepatitis A, Typhoid 
• Bites and stings – eg, Jelly fish, Scorpion, Rabies 
• Environmental contact – eg, Cutaneous larva migrans, Leptospirosis, Schistosomiasis, Tetanus
}}

Name 2 vaccines which can be mandatory. {{c1::Yellow fever and meningococcal vaccine }}
 
• Women should wait {{c1::>4}} weeks before conceiving after a live vaccines

Vaccine-preventable Travel-related Diseases

Which are the odd ones out?

• Chikungunya
• Cholera 
• Dengue
• Diphtheria 
• Hepatitis A 
• Hepatitis B
• Hepatitis C 
• Influenza 
• Japanese Encephalitis 
• Lyme
• Malaria
• Measles 
• Meningococcal 
• Mumps 
• Pertussis 
• Pneumococcal 
• Poliomyelitis 
• Rabies 
• Rubella 
• Tetanus 
• Tick-borne Encephalitis 
• Tuberculosis 
• Typhoid 
• Varicella 
• West Nile
• Yellow Fever
• Zika

{{c1::Not vaccine preventable - 
Malaria, 
Dengue, 
Chikungunya, 
Zika , 
West Nile,
(^vaccine in the works)

Hepatitis C,
 Lyme}}

Drug-Travel Vaccine Interactions 
• Space vaccines at least {{c1::2.5}}cm apart if administered in same limb 
• {{c1::Live attenuated}} vaccines should be avoided in patients taking immunomodulators, cytotoxic agents, antimetabolites, and high-dose steroids 
• Delay live oral typhoid (>3 days) and oral cholera (>14 days) vaccine after administration of {{c1::antibiotics}} 
• Use {{c1::IM}} rabies vaccine in patients taking chloroquine

Vaccine Preparation and Administration

• Follow guidelines for choice of needle based on {{c1::adiposity}}
• Vaccines containing an adjuvant should be injected in Children <3 yrs in the {{c1::Upper middle anterolateral thigh}} (point on yourself)

What is the deltoid safe triangle? What features does it miss?
{{c1::
Area of injection, radial nerve + brachial artery

}}

Why would a deep subcutaneous injection be given?
If bleeding disorder present risk of IM haematoma

• Yellow fever may be given {{c1::subcutaneously}} 
• {{c1::Rabies+BCG}} may be given intradermally

If a person has an allergic reaction to eggs resulting in hives, which of the following vaccines can you give yellow fever or influenza vaccine?
{{c1::Both under emergency prepared conditions}}

Yellow Fever
• Single-stranded RNA {{c1::Flavi}}virus 
• Transmitted by Aedes or Haemagogus {{c1::mosquitoes}} 
• Increased risk in rainy season 
• Recent large outbreaks of YF in eastern Brazil (2017/18) 

• Countries with risk of YF virus transmission
- 29 in Africa and 13 in Central and South America

• Risk of rare serious adverse events – Yellow fever vaccine associated {{c1::neurologic/viscerotropic}} disease

Contraindications to YF Vaccine 
• Allergy to vaccine component 
• Age < {{c1:6 months }}
• HIV, if CD4 count <{{c1::200}}/mm3 

Which disease is not CI?
• Thymoma in myasthenia gravis 
• Diabetes
• Primary immunodeficiencies 
• Malignancy 
• Pregnancy
• Transplantation 
• Immunosuppressive and immunomodulatory drugs

{{c1::Diabetes and Pregnancy}}

Rabies  
• Pre-exposure prophylaxis: give the interval between days of treatment {{c1::days 0, 7, 21-28}} 
• Wound management 
• Post-exposure prophylaxis: IM rabies vaccine on days {{c1::0, 3}} if vaccinated

• Human Rabies {{c1::Immunoglobulin}} on day 0 and IM rabies vaccine on (give interval again) {{c1::days 0, 3, 7, 14}} if unvaccinated

Hepatitis
Hepatitis A + Typhoid 
• Single dose + booster of hepatitis A ({{c1::6 months – 1 year}}) and typhoid ({{c1::3 years}}) Give time between shots

Hepatitis A + B 
• Standard - 0, 1 month, 6 months 
• Accelerated - 0, 1 week, {{c1::3-4 weeks}}, 1 year
• Measure anti-HB{{c1::sAg}} antibodies in at-risk adults at 1-3 months following completion of series

Pregnancy and Travel Vaccines
• Tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis vaccine should be given between {{c1::27}} and {{c1::36}} weeks gestation 
• Vaccines are not recommended unless there is a specified risk to the mother, True or False? {{c1::False, Annual inactivated influenza vaccine is recommended }}
• Certain vaccines, including hepatitis A/B and {{c1::meningococcal}} vaccines may be indicated based on risk. 
• Rabies post-exposure prophylaxis should be given after low-moderate risk rabies exposure during travel. True or false? {{c1::False, moderate-high risk}} 
• Avoid live-virus vaccines, except yellow fever vaccine, for which pregnancy is considered a precaution. True or false? {{c1::True, but you can issue a medical waiver if risks of vaccination outweigh risks of YF exposure. }}
• Wait at least {{c1::4}} weeks after live-virus vaccine before conceiving.

Malaria
What are the ABCDE of malaria?
{{c1::
• Awareness of risk 
• Bite prevention 
•Chemoprophylaxis (if indicated) 
• Diagnosis 
• Emergency self treatment (if appropriate)
}}

Chemoprophylaxis
Atovaquone-proguanil 
Daily; well tolerated; good for last minute travellers; avoid in {{c1::severe renal impairment }}

Chloroquine 
Weekly; can be used in pregnancy; may worsen {{c1::psoriasis}}
 
Doxycycline 
Daily; may prevent rickettsia or leptospirosis; avoid in {{c1::pregnancy}} and < 8 years; photosensitivity in 3% 

Mefloquine 
{{c1::Weekly}}; safe in pregnancy; no longer licensed in Ireland; {{c1::psychiatric}} side effects
 
Primaquine/Tafenoquine 
Primaquine (P. vivax) | Tafenoquine (vivax and falciparum); cannot be used in {{c1::G6PD}} deficiency

If you think you got malaria what should you do?
{{c1::Give yourself Atovaquone-proguanil or Artemether-lumafantrine immediately and seek a medical facility}}
